attributes.title: Habit Formation in Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD): Protocol for a scoping review

summary.value:
ADHD has been related to poorer outcomes in domains such as sleep, diet, exercise, or addiction. A common feature to all of them is that they could be described as a kind of habit formation. Hence, to study if, or how, habit formation has been linked to ADHD in scientific literature is of importance to understand a prominent feature of the disorder. 
We aim to carry out a scoping review that explores how habit formation has been related to ADHD in the scientific literature.

registration_responses.summary:
ADHD has been related to poorer outcomes in domains such as sleep, diet, exercise, or addiction. A common feature to all of them is that they could be described as a kind of habit formation. Hence, to study if, or how, habit formation has been linked to ADHD in scientific literature is of importance to understand a prominent feature of the disorder. 
We aim to carry out a scoping review that explores how habit formation has been related to ADHD in the scientific literature.

attributes.title: Implicit Affect in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder

q1.value: A pre-registered replication of affective congruence in PTSD

q3.value: Implicit processes play an important role in posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Theoretical frameworks for PTSD often highlight the role of implicit memory in perpetuating PTSD symptoms; likewise, research in implicit self-concept has shown that people with PTSD show negative associations with their implicit self-concepts. Little research has investigated the role of implicit affect in PTSD, despite emotional dysregulation being a core feature of the disorder. A recent study by the first author of this pre-registration found that the association between implicit and explicit affect was moderated by PTSD symptoms in an online sample of trauma-exposed participants. Specifically, the association between implicit negative affect and implicit negative affect was non-significant at high levels of PTSD symptoms despite being positively correlated at low and moderate levels of PTSD. This study aims to replicate these findings in another online sample of participants.

q4.value:
All hypotheses are directly derived from the previous study. 

1. PTSD will moderate the relationship between implicit negative affect, and explicit negative affect, such that the congruence of implicit and explicit negative affect will lessen as PTSD increases. 
2. PTSD will moderate the relationship between implicit positive affect and explicit positive affect, such that the congruence of implicit and explicit positive affect will increase as PTSD increases. 
3. Action orientation will moderate the moderating effect of PTSD symptoms on the implicit - explicit positive affect relationship, such that among individuals with high PTSD symptoms, higher action orientation is associated with greater positive affect congruence. 
4. Action orientation will moderate the moderating effect of PTSD symptoms on the implicit - explicit positive affect relationship, such that among individuals with high PTSD symptoms, higher action orientation is associated with great negative affect congruence.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: There are no experimental manipulations; additionally, there is no contact between personnel and study subjects.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: NOTE: pre-registered analyses are being registered prior to any human observation of the data; however, the data was spot-checked when 3 participants and 12 participants had been sampled only to make sure there were no issues with the data collection (e.g., making sure participants were able to complete the study in the right amount of time, checking responses to "what did you think this study was about?" to make sure no one reported issues with the study).

question.value: Data will be collected via amazon mechanical turk; it will be required that participants have a 99% approval rating, at least 100 tasks completed and less than 10,000 tasks completed, and US location. Participants will be compensated $3.75 for their 25 minute participation.

q14.value: Note that these analyses are part of a larger, validation study that is collecting 300 participants. Trauma-exposed participants will be taken from the larger dataset for the pre-registered analyses to be conducted on. Therefore, a sample size cannot be completely determined for this study. In past studies by the first author, usually at least half of participants identify a stressor event that meets DSM-5 criteria for trauma.

question.value:
Implicit Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (IPANAT; cite): measures implicit positive and negative affect
Disguised Mood Measure (cite): measures implicit positive and negative affect
Explicit Affect: internally generated explicit measure of affect that has the same emotion word items and response scale as the IPANAT
Life Events Checklist (LEC-5; Weathers et al., 2013): measure of trauma exposure
Posttraumatic Stress Checklist (PCL-5; Weathers et al., 2013): measure of PTSD symptoms associated with a specific event
Action orientation (AO; Kuhl, 1994): measure of volitional ability
Demographics

Implicit Negative Affect: sum of IPANAT - negative affect items
Implicit Positive Affect: sum of IPANAT - positive affect items
Explicit Negative Affect: sum of explicit affect - negative affect items
Explicit Positive Affect: sum of explicit affect - positive affect items
Cumulative trauma: sum of different traumas exposed to, as measured by the LEC-5
PTSD symptoms: sum of PTSD symptoms, as measured by the PCL-5
action orientation: sum of action orientation responses
Moderated linear regressions will be used to test the moderating effect of PTSD symptoms and action orientation on the relationship between implicit and explicit affect.

q22.value: Cases where one or both of the attention check questions have been failed will be excluded. Cases where more than 30% of the data is missing will be excluded. Open-ended questions will be assessed; if responses to the open-ended questions are non-sensical, that case will be excluded.

q23.value: missing data will be imputed via maximum likelihood elaboration estimation using AMOS

q24.value:
The larger study these analyses are part of includes a new measure of implicit affect. The analyses outlined in this pre-registration may also test the hypotheses with this new measure of implicit affect to compare the two measures. 
Other analysis methods may be used for testing congruence; polynomial regression analysis with response surface analysis has been used to test congruence in the past and this may be applied as well. 
Cumulative trauma (number of unique traumas exposed to) may also be investigated as a predictor of affect congruence.

A recent study by the first author of this pre-registration found that the association between implicit and explicit affect was moderated by PTSD symptoms in an online sample of trauma-exposed participants. Specifically, the association between implicit negative affect and implicit negative affect was non-significant at high levels of PTSD symptoms despite being positively correlated at low and moderate levels of PTSD. This study aims to replicate these findings in another online sample of participants.

summary.value: This is a preregistration of the idea, method, and hypothesis associated with this project. No analysis plan was included for this sample, but analysis plans are present in later registrations. The attached document was originally uploaded to this project on Feb 2015, before data analysis had begun. The registration was not done properly at that time, so I am officially registering this document now.

attributes.title: Extent of use of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning protocols in cancer diagnosis: a Systematic Literature Review
attributes.description: To explore the extent of actual use of AI/ ML protocols for diagnosing cancer in prospective (clinical trial or real-world) setting

q1.value: Extent of use of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning protocols in cancer diagnosis: a Systematic Literature Review

q3.value: There is an ever-increasing presence of Artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) in the medical field, especially in the realm of diagnosis. A large number of AI/ML protocols and devices working on AI/ML principles have seen validation using retrospective patient data and idealised databases. We were interested to see how many AI/ML protocols have been actually used in the diagnosis of cancer in a prospective (clinical trial/ real world) basis.

q4.value: The extent of actual usage of Artificial intelligence protocols in cancer diagnosis resulting in a clinical decision making is lower than the number of artificial intelligence protocols being validated and tested

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review of published literature of studies discussing the actual usage of artificial intelligence in cancer diagnosis wherein the diagnosis by the AI protocol resulted in or helped in clinical decision making

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Searching of database: PubMed/ MEDLINE

PICO details for the systematic literature review:
Population: Humans, any type of cancer
Intervention: AI/ ML protocol used for diagnosis, including colonoscopy and other similar interventions; AI/ML protocol diagnosis should be used for clinical decision making
Comparator: any comparator
Outcome: Any outcome which describes application of AI/ML in cancer diagnostics
Study design: clinical trials, prospective studies, real-world studies
Language: only English language articles will be included

After execution of search strategy, two independent reviewers will scan the titles and abstract to include all relevant articles for full text analysis. After full text analysis of all relevant papers by two independent reviewers, eligible papers shall be taken up for data extraction. Disagreements between individual judgements will be resolved by mediation of a third reviewer. All data will be recorded in Microsoft Excel.

Risk of bias (quality assessment) will be done using Cochrane risk of bias tool

q13.value: PubMed shall be searched from the date of inception till 5th January 2020. A minimum of 10 full text articles should be identified for us to proceed with the analysis.

question.value: How many published studies have reported an actual usage of an AI protocol for cancer diagnosis, in a prospective (clinical trial/ real world) setting? Is there a comparison between human diagnosis and AI diagnosis? What is the sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive values of the diagnosis by the AI protocol?
Descriptive analysis will be used. Since we are not planning a meta-analysis, we shall not be using any statistical methods to evaluate the data.

q22.value:
Exclusion criteria: we shall exclude all retrieved published articles which satisfy these exclusion criteria:
Population:Non-humans (animals, cell line); Non-cancer
Intervention: AI/ ML protocol used for anything other than diagnosis (eg, Robotic surgeries, prognosis, post-diagnosis therapy applications etc)
Outcomes: Outcome of a study is not related to the actual usage of AI/ML protocol in prospective basis 
Study design: Retrospective studies, all types of review articles, editorial, letter to editors etc (all papers which are not prospective, clinical trial/ real-world papers will be excluded)
Language: all papers not in English language shall be excluded

q23.value: If a full text of an article is not available,it will be excluded, and the reason given shall be 'full text not available'

q25.value: Studies from all over the  world shall be included in this systematic literature review

registration_responses.q3: There is an ever-increasing presence of Artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) in the medical field, especially in the realm of diagnosis. A large number of AI/ML protocols and devices working on AI/ML principles have seen validation using retrospective patient data and idealised databases. We were interested to see how many AI/ML protocols have been actually used in the diagnosis of cancer in a prospective (clinical trial/ real world) basis.

attributes.title: The Benefit of Antiretroviral Therapy During the Acute Phase of Infection among People Living with HIV: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis.

q1.value: The Benefit of Antiretroviral Therapy During the Acute Phase of Infection among People Living with HIV: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis.

q2.value: Da Wang, Yang Zhang, Aixin Li, Meixia Gao, Tong Zhang, Hao Wu, Xiaojie Huang, Guanzhi Chen

q3.value: Acute HIV infection (AHI) is characterized by high viral replication and increased infectiousness. During this time the immunization of most PLWHA is slightly impaired and the latent viral reservoir is established, which is the source of viral rebound and the major obstacle in eradicating the latent human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1). The benefit of initiating ART early in HIV infection has been certified that rapidly suppresses HIV replication and increases the recovery of CD4 cell counts, and may prevent persistent immune activation and inflammation, but their validity has not been characterized during acute infection. Herein, we systematically reviewed the literature to assess the effectiveness of antiretroviral therapy in patients starting in the acute phase of HIV infection.

q4.value: PLWHA starting ART during acute-stage disease would have a better prognosis.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We identified studies published between 1 January 2000 and 1 Dec 2019 which reported the initiation of ART in the acute phase of HIV infection. Through systematic literature searches and discussion with investigators. In this systematic review and Meta-analysis, we performed a comprehensive database searching in PubMed, Web of Science, EMBASE, and were done with medical subject headings and free text in English relating to “HIV/AIDS”, “acute-phase infection”, and “ART”. There are no research type restrictions on the studies we included.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
We included studies of comparing antiretroviral therapy in acute and chronic stage among people living with HIV, in which had a clear indication of when to start antiretroviral therapy. To be included, participants aged 18 and above, except pregnant women, and no geographical restrictions. Cross-sectional, cohort, case–control and randomized controlled trials were eligible for inclusion. Study selection criteria only original studies were considered. Reviews, conference abstracts, unpublished manuscripts and non-English papers were excluded. Studies with different definitions of disease stage were excluded. In addition, studies were also excluded if they reported predicted outcomes rather than actual outcomes, and could not obtain or calculate corresponding data. 
Two investigators (Da Wang and Aixin Li) screened all titles and abstracts identified in the initial search and excluded studies in violation of the inclusion criteria. Two investigators (Da Wang and Meixia Gao) assessed the full texts and data extraction. In cases of disagreement, consensus was achieved through referral to a third reviewer (Yang Zhang).

q13.value: The data have not been extracted by our collaborators.

question.value: We included studies of comparing antiretroviral therapy in acute and chronic stage among people living with HIV. Information from the included studies was extracted after review, including author, study design, study period, publication year, follow-up period, sample sizes, the definition of acute infection, comparator groups, treatment options, geographical location and outcomes. The effectiveness of therapy is measured by counting the number of disease outcomes.

Quality and risk of bias assessment will conduct on included studies using aspects of the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool for randomized trials and the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for non-randomized trials and observational studies. We will use Revman 5.3 software for analysis and used forest map and funnel plot to detect bias. For pooled data, the I² statistic will be used to estimate heterogeneity and risk of bias, specifically publication bias.
